PVC piping- Schedule 80 PVC piping is used to convey chlorine gas, under vacuum, from the chlorinators to the injectors and chlorine solution, under pressure, from the injectors to the various chlorination locations.  No inspection or testing is required for the piping under vacuum conditions since the piping is under vacuum and is inherently safe.  If the piping develops a leak or otherwise fails, vacuum is lost and the flow of chlorine gas is immediately halted by the vacuum regulator.  In addition, a vacuum alarm condition will result which will alert system operators of the loss of chlorine feed.  The chlorine solution piping is not regulated under the PSM standard and inspection and testing is not required.

Valves 
Two types of valves are used in the chlorination system.


a.	Standard ton container valves- The valves on the ton container are industry standard valves.  No maintenance on the valves is attempted with the possible exception of tightening the packing if a leak develops.  If a valve is found to be defective, the other container valve may be used or the container is returned to the supplier.  In addition, an auxiliary container isolating valve is used to prevent moisture from entering the piping system during a container changeout.  This isolating valve is the same type of valve as the container valve.
b.	PVC ball valves- Numerous PVC ball valves are installed on the chlorine gas (vacuum) and chlorine solution lines.  The valves used for vacuum service may require replacement of internal gaskets, O-rings, etc.  These valves are included in the PM system and are exercised regularly.  Kits for re-building these valves are kept in stock in storage at Central Pumping Station.

4.6 	COMPLIANCE AUDITS

The risk management program for WPS #1 will be reviewed periodically to ensure that personnel are implementing it properly.  An audit will be conducted to review each of the preventative program elements to ensure that each is up-to-date; that each is being implemented; identify any problem areas; and take corrective action where needed.

Pursuant to Program 2 requirements, a risk management program audit will be conducted at least every three years.  The audit team will certify that they have evaluated complian

American Industrial Classification System codes.  

A planned inspection of WPS #1 by MIOSHA staff on March 19, 2009, was not conducted as the enforcement staff determined that the station was not subject to the Process Safety Management requirements due to the lack of full time staffing at the station.  

Therefore, by default, the operation of WPS#1 falls under Program 2 requirements that imposes streamlined prevention program requirements, as well as additional hazard assessment, management, and emergency response requirements.  


2.0  MANAGEMENT SYSTEM [68.15]

Under Program 2 the management system requirements are:

1)	To develop a management system to oversee  the implementation of the risk management program elements;
2)	To designate a qualified person or position with the overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the risk management program elements; and
3)	To document the names of people or positions and define the lines of authority through an organizational chart or other similar document, if you assign responsibility for implementing individual requirements of the risk management program to people or positions other than the person or position with overall responsibility for the risk management program.

The Public Services Managing Director has overall responsibility for overseeing and directing the department's activities and operations.  Various responsibilities are delegated down through the department's organization to the managers and supervisors reporting directly or indirectly to the managing director.  The Water Operation/Maintenance group has responsibility for the operation of the municipal water supply system.  This group is responsible for the day to day operation of all water  system by managing the production and distribution of drinking water across a multiple pressure district system consisting of pumping stations, storage tanks and booster/bleed stations.  This group also conducts the

daily inspections of all operating water pumping stations, including WPS #1 (Central). This group, therefore, is responsible for assuring that the chlorine storage and feed system is being operated efficiently and safely and in compliance with the Risk Management Program requirements.

The Environmental Services Superintendent (ESS) manages the Environmental Services Division that has the responsibility of developing and maintaining many of the environmental and safety compliance programs that impact the department's operations.  The ESS has overall responsibility for the development, maintenance, and compliance monitoring of the risk management program elements.  In carrying out this responsibility, the Environmental Services Superintendent works directly with the Water Operation and Maintenance Supervisor and also with Operator/Maintainer personnel during the program implementation, maintenance and training of the RMP.  However, various other individuals within the Public Services Department are also involved in specific elements of the Risk Management Program as presented in table of assignment of risk management responsibilities.  
 
The individuals involved in this program meet periodically to review all aspects of the various program elements as they relate to the chlorine system at WPS #1.  Each member of the team should be allowed to report on any activities that pertain to their area of responsibility.   In terms of accountability each of the key positions having direct RMP responsibilities are directly reportable, as shown on the following department organizational chart, to the department's managing director.


3.0  HAZARD ASSESSMENT [68.20 - 68.42]

3.1	OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSES
As shown in Section 2.0 of  this RMP, the chlorine storage and feed system located at Central Pumping Station meets RMP Program 2 criteria.  As such, the RMP is required to identify, analyze and report one worst-case scenario to represent all of the toxic regulated

substances (i.e., chlorine) held above threshold quantities (i.e., 2500 lbs) in Program 2 processes. 

In addition, an alternative release scenario analysis is also required to identify the potential reach and effect of hypothetical accidental releases under more realistic circumstances.

The regulations require use of tables or models for atmospheric dispersion analysis that appropriately account for gas density.  The OCA was completed using EPA's software program, RMP*CompTM that performs calculations described in the USEPA's RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance. In order to complete the Offsite Consequence Analyses (OCA), Appendix F:  Supplemental Risk Management Program Guidance for Wastewater Treatment Plants was used since use of chlorine at Central is similar to how it is used at a WWTP.  This guidance provides additional information for wastewater treatment plants (or water pumping stations using chlorine).  The tables and charts from the above referenced guidance that were used to complete the OCA are included in Appendix A. 

At this point it should be noted that all 1-ton chlorine cylinders are stored inside the pumping station building.  In addition, the active 1-ton cylinder that is feeding chlorine to the water distribution system is also located within an area that includes a caustic scrubber system that is designed to capture a release from an entire 1-ton cylinder and treat it without allowing a discharge of chlorine gas to the atmosphere.  In essence, if a chlorine leak were to occur in a ton cylinder that is connected to the vacuum feed system and the contents of the cylinder were released, the scrubber will respond and the release of chlorine gas to the atmosphere would be minimal.  These additional factors help to mitigate the worst-case release scenario. ce with the prevention program requirements for the chlorination system.  The audit team will consist of the Water Operation and Maintenance Supervisor, Environmental Services Superintendent, and additional operator/maintainers.  A report of the findings will be developed that will determine and document the particular response to each of the audit findings.  Essentially, the correction of each deficiency found during the audit must be documented.

The audit will be conducted using the WPS #1 Chlorination System Compliance Audit Form that is included in Appendix L.  The checklist will be used as part of a walkthrough of the WPS#1 chlorination system. 4.7 	Incident Investigation

Incidents can provide valuable information about site hazards and the steps needed to prevent accidental releases.  Each incident that resulted in, or could have resulted in, a catastrophic release of chlor

ine gas must be investigated.  A catastrophic release is one that presents an imminent and substantial endangerment to public health and the environment.  If the incident meets the criteria for including in the five-year accident history section of your RMP, it warrants an incident investigation.  Minor accidents or near misses will also be investigated in order to help identify problems that could lead to more serious accidents.

Any incidents that result, or could reasonably result, in the catastrophic release of chlorine are to be investigated as soon as possible but no later than 48 hours of occurrence.  Any incidents involving chlorine will be investigated by a team with at least one member knowledgeable in the chlorination process.  If a contract employee is involved, the contractor must also be included on the investigation team.  The investigations will be included in a report to identify the factors contributing to the incident.  The purpose of the report will be to assist management take corrective measures.  The incidents findings and recommendations will be addressed promptly.  An action register will be created that identifies the items needing corrective action with an assignment of responsibility and target dates to resolve the issues.  The results of the report will be shared with the water operator/maintainer staff.  The incident report will be retained on file for at least five years.

If the incident included an occupational injury or illness, the investigators are to use the following form titled Accident/Incident Investigation Report.  This form is to be used throughout the department for all incidents that result in personal injury or property damage.   near miss is also to be investigated.  An example of a near miss is the dropping of a full one-ton container of chlorine from the hoist during transfer from the storage area to the container room.  Even though there may not have been a release due to this incident, a catastrophic rel

ease could reasonably have resulted.  
 
5.0	EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Water Pump Station #1 (Central) is a non-responding facility as defined in § 68.90(b).  Essentially, if a chlorine release occurs at Central the response procedures are purposed to ensure the safety of department personnel.  The water operator/maintainer personnel will not respond to a catastrophic release of chlorine from the facility.  If a release occurs from one of the two chlorine 1-ton cylinders in the Chlorine Room, the lease will be detected which will, in turn, activate the caustic scrubber system thus mitigating a catastrophic release.


However, Public Services staff has developed the Kalamazoo Water Pumping & Distribution System Emergency Response Plan (ERP).  The ERP is a multi-disaster plan includes a chlorine gas release from Central as one of the scenarios.  For the chlorine gas release scenario, the ERP includes the threat evaluation and response procedures.  Excerpts from ERP pertaining to responses to a chlorine release (Part 2.5 and Part 4.1 of the Kalamazoo Water System ERP) are included in Appendix E of this written program.

Procedures for notifying the local emergency response agencies about accidental releases.  The agencies that will respond are the City of Kalamazoo Department of Public Safety and Kalamazoo County Office of Emergency Management (OEM).  The Kalamazoo Department of Public Safety (KDPS), an integrated police and fire department will be responsible for notifying the public in the City of Kalamazoo.  The KDPS has mutual aid agreements with surrounding jurisdictions, including the City of Parchment and Kalamazoo Township.  

The KDPS will be the first responder to a chlorine gas release at Central.  If needed, KDPS will notify additional emergency response agencies depending on the severity of the release. Kalamazoo Area Water System Overview

The City of Kalamazoo Public Water Supply System is designed, operated, and maintained by the Kalamazoo Public Services Department, Water Division. (KPSWD). The mission and the purpose of the System is to provide a safe, sufficient, reliable water supply and related services to the public within the Kalamazoo metropolitan area. Ground water provides 100 percent of the water served. The average daily flow rate is about 23 MGD.

Chlorine is used to disinfect the water prior to supply. Chlorine is delivered and used in one ton containers. The containers are stored in storage room.  The Water Supply System uses vacuum system that is inherently safe. These systems involve the use of water flowing through an eductor which creates vacuum. This vacuum allows for the feed of chlorine from the containers into the piping system. If a chlorine line downstream of the vacuum regulator is broken or develops a leak, the vacuum is interrupted and the vacuum regulator automatically closes, preventing discharge of chlorine.

Water Pumping Station #1 Central Overview

Central Pumping Station #1 is located at 215 W. Stockbridge Ave. in the City of Kalamazoo.  It is bounded on the north and west side by W. Crosstown Parkway, on the east side by Stockbridge Ave., on the south side by a commercial business and Balch Street.

There are a total of six wells located on the property, which supply raw water to the pumping station.  The original pumping Station #1 was built in 1884 and has been abandoned.  The present facility was built in 1995.  The six wells provide a raw water capacity of 6,750 gallons per minute (gpm), or 9.73 million gallons per day (MGD).  There are two 200, one 150, and one 100 hp treated water pumps at this station.  Iron is removed from the raw water through air stripping towers and filters.  Central Pumping Station #1 is on of the two iron filtration plants on the system and is an unmanned facility.  The treated water is

stored in a clear well.  The pumping station supplies the Low Pressure District.

The pumping station is a two-story building with multiple floor levels and a high rise section that encloses the air strippers.  It is a cast-in-place concrete structure with concrete columns, and concrete floors.  The walls are concrete block with a brick face on the exterior.  The high rise section is a steel framed structure with pre-cast wall sections.  The roof is made of pre-cast concrete planks, with elastomeric sheet roofing.

All of the water division's chemicals, including one ton and 150 pound chlorine cylinders, and other chemicals, used in the treatment process by the Water Division, are delivered to and stored at Central Water Pumping Station.  The chlorine storage area was designed to store a maximum of eight one-ton cylinders, and forty 150-pound cylinders.  All other chemicals are stored in the Chemical Storage Area.  Chlorine and all other chemicals are delivered to other remote stations as needed. Chlorine and chemical feed rooms are provided, adjacent to the storage rooms, for treating the water.  There is a chlorine detector mounted in the storage area to detect chlorine leaks.  In the event of the major chlorine leak, an Emergency Chlorine Scrubber is provided to scrub chlorine from the air in the storage area.

Chlorination System Overview
The objective if chlorinating is to destroy pathogenic organisms in the untreated groundwater to insure safe drinking water.  A chlorine/water solution is injecte3d into the untreated water before the booster pump distributes the then treated water to the

distribution system.  Chlorine oxidizes the pathogenic bacteria by rupturing their cell walls.  This is called lysis.

Chlorine is applied at a rate of 1 to 4 ppm to insure a free chlorine residual of at least 1.0 ppm throughout the distribution system.  The addition of chlorine is controlled automatically at Pumping Station #1.  Manual adjustments may be made at WPS #1 by changing the application rate on the automation equipment control units.  The operator shall take daily DPD readings from the finished water sample tap to insure adequate chlorination.

1.0 Applicability to 40 CFR Part 68

1.1 General Applicability
If a tank, drum, container, pipe, or other process at a facility contains any of the extremely hazardous toxic and flammable substances listed in the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) at 40 CFR 68.130 in an amount above the threshold quantity specified for that substance, the facility is required to develop and implement a risk management program under a rule issued by the USEPA.

The goal of part 68 and the risk management program it requires is to prevent accidental releases of substances that can cause serious harm to the public and the environment from short-term exposures and to mitigate the severity of releases that do occur.  Under the Clean Air Act (CAA), EPA was required to issue a rule specifying the types of actions to be taken by facilities (referred to in the law as stationary sources) to prevent accidental releases of such hazardous chemicals into the atmosphere and reduce t

heir potential impact on the public and the environment.  Part 68 is that rule.

Part 68 applies if:
1.	If it is a stationary source (facility)
2.	If the facility manages a regulated substance
3.	If the facility manages a regulated substance in quantities exceeding regulated threshold quantities
4.	And it is defined as a process

The CAA defines stationary sources as, any buildings, structures, equipment, installations, or substance emitting stationary activities.  Central is a structure that stores both 1-ton and 150 lb chlorine gas cylinders.  Chlorine is fed to the drinking water system from the 1-ton cylinders utilizing a vacuum feed system.  Therefore, WPS #1 meets the definition of a facility.

The list of substances regulated under Part 68.130 is in Appendix A of the rule.  Chlorine gas is included on the list of regulated substances.  The maximum threshold quantity for chlorine gas is 2500 lbs.  

The chlorine used and stored at the WPS #1 is delivered in one-ton and 150# cylinders.  The 150# cylinders are delivered in storage racks of six cylinders attached to one rack with a maximum intended inventory of 16 racks resulting in a maximum intended storage volume in 150# cylinders of 14,400 lbs of chlorine. 

In addition, Water Pumping Station #1 has provisions for storing a maximum intended inventory of eight one ton cylinders (including the ones in use).  Therefore the maximum intended inventory of chlorine stored/used in one ton cylinders is 16,000 lbs.  Therefore, the maximum intended inventory of chlorine in one ton and 150 lb cylinders is 30,400 lbs.  Therefore the quantity of chlorine managed in the facility exceeds the regulatory threshold quantity.

Process is defined in 40 CFR 68.3 as, Any activity involving a regulated substance, including any use, storage, manufacturing, handling, or on-site movement of such substances, or combination of these activities.  Any group of vessels that are interconnected, or separate vessels th

at are located such that a regulated substance could be involved in a potential release, shall be considered a single process.  Since a cylinder is considered a vessel, the chlorine storage and feed system is considered a single process.

Therefore, from the above discussion, the Central chlorine storage and feed system is subject to the CAA 40 CFR Part 68 risk management program regulations.

1.2 Applicability of Program Levels
Once it was determined that the Central chlorine feed system is subject to the CAA risk management rule, it was necessary to determine what actions must be taken to comply with the rule.  The rule defines three Program levels based on processes' relative potential for public impacts and the level of effort needed to prevent accidents.  For each Program level, the rule defines requirements that reflect the level of risk and effort associated with the processes at that level.

Program 1:  Processes which would not affect the public in the case of a worst-case release and with no accidents with specific offsite consequences within the past five years.

Program 2:  Processes not eligible for Program 1 or subject to Program 3 are placed in Program 2, which imposes streamlined prevention program requirement, as well as additional hazard assessment, management, and emergency response requirements.

Program 3:  Processes not eligible for Program 1 and either subject to OSHA's PSM standard under federal or state OSHA programs or classified in one of ten specified North American Industrial Classification System (NAICS) codes.

Pursuant to the above criteria, WPS #1 falls under the Program 2 requirements because the operation is not eligible for Program 1 due to the location of the facility in proximity to residences, hospital, and commercial establishments; the process is not subject to MIOSHA PSM because there are no Public Services employees stationed at this location; and the process does not fall under any of the ten specified North

3.3.4	Environmental Receptors Within the Distance

Environmental receptors are defined as natural areas such as national or state parks, forests, or monuments; officially designated wildlife sanctuaries, preserves or areas; and Federal wilderness areas that could be exposed at any time to toxic concentrations of chemicals as a result of an accidental release.

There are no such environmental receptors within the 0.1-mile radius from WPS #1 that has been determined to be in the area potentially affected by the alternative-case release.

For WPS #1, the Five-Year Accident History will cover any accidental release associated with the chlorine storage and feed equipment.

WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO

The USEPA requires that the City develop a worst-case release scenario from WPS #1 (Central) for planning purposes.  The USEPA has defined the worst-case scenario as the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance (i.e., chlorine) from a single vessel or process line failure that results in the greatest distance to an endpoint.

WPS #1 uses chlorine in 2000-pound (one-ton) containers.  Therefore the worst-case release scenario assumes that the entire 2000-pound quantity of chlorine gas is released completely over a 10-minute period.  It is also assumed that the release occurs outdoors such that mitigative effects of a building and the chlorine scrubber cannot be considered.

3.2.3	Public Receptors within the Distance

A map of a portion of the Kalamazoo area that would be potentially affected by the worst-case scenario is included in Appendix A.  The 1.3-mile distance to the toxic endpoint is indicated on the map.

The area of this circle is 5.3 square miles.  The area consists of a mix of residential, industrial, commercial, and open spaces.  Discussion with City staff indicates that the approximate mix of these various land uses is somewhat in proportion to the City of Kalamazoo as a whole.  Therefore, to estimate the potential population affected by a worst-case release scenario, the population density for the City of Kalamazoo will be used.

The population of the city was estimated using 2012 census data for the City of Kalamazoo, a compilation of data made available by the Census Bureau.  According to this data, the population of the City of Kalamazoo is 74,262 and the land area of the city is 24.6 square miles.  Therefore, the population density of the city is 3,018 persons per square mile.

Using this population density and the area that could potentially be affected by the worst-case release, the population that could potentially be impacted is determined to be approximately 15,995.

4.1.1  	Chlorine (Material) Safety Data Sheets
The MSDS for Chlorine is included in Appendix B.  Chlorine gas is primarily a respiratory irritant.  It is so irritating that low concentrations in air are readily detectable by the normal person.  The odor threshold of chlorine is about 0.1 PPM.  At low concentrations, chlorine gas has an odor similar to household bleach.  As the concentrations increase from the level of detection by smell so does symptomatology in the exposed individual.  The impact of exposure to chlorine is both concentration and time dependent.  At chlorine concentrations above 5 PPM, the gas is very irritating and it is unlikely that any person would remain in such an exposure for more than a very brief time unl

ess trapped or unconscious. (Ref 4-1)

4.1.1.1  Acute Toxicity
In concentrations near the threshold of smell, chlorine gas will, after several hours of exposure, cause mild irritation of the eyes and of the mucous membranes of the respiratory tract.  As concentrations increase, there is an increase in the irritating effect on the eyes, coughing mechanism and on the upper and lower respiratory tract with eventual difficulty in breathing.  As the duration of exposure and/or concentration increase, the affected individual may become apprehensive and restless with coughing accompanied by throat irritation, sneezing, and excess salivation.  At higher levels, there is vomiting associated with labored breathing.  In extreme cases, difficulty in breathing can progress to the point of death through suffocation.

Low concentrations of chlorine gas in the air may have minor irritating effects or may produce slight symptoms after several hours of exposure, but careful examination of persons repeatedly exposed to such conditions reportedly has shown no permanent physiological effect.  The lowest lethal limit for chlorine is estimated to be 430 PPM over a 30 minute exposure time.  This value is related to respiratory exposure.  A few breaths of chlorine in concentrations over 1,000 PPM can be fatal. (Ref 4-2)

Gaseous chlorine combines with water (e.g. perspiration) to form weak hypochlorous acid.  This weak acid can create mild skin burns with symptoms such as discomfort or rash.  Such burns will become apparent most quickly in the sensitive areas of the body, such as around the genitals, between the buttocks, or under the arms.  Liquid chlorine in contact with the eyes or skin will cause local irritation and/or burns.  All symptoms and signs result directly or indirectly from its irritating action.  Liquid chlorine is a very cold liquid, boiling at -34°C (-9°F).  Contact with liquid chlorine will result in frost bite.

missible Exposure Limit (PEL) for chlorine is 1.0 PPM or 3.0 mg/m3.  At no time shall a worker be exposed to concentrations in excess of this concentration.

The ACGIH Threshold Limit Value-Time Weighted Average (TLV-TWA) for chlorine is 0.5 PPM or 1.5 mg/m3.  This is the concentration for a normal 8-hour workday and a 40-hour workweek, to which nearly all workers may be exposed, day after day, without adverse effect.

 
The ACGIH Threshold Limit Value-Short-Term Exposure Limit (TLV-STEL) is 1.0 PPM or 2.9 mg/m3.  This is the concentration to which workers can be exposed continuously for a short period without suffering acute effects provided that the TLV-TWA is not exceeded.  The TLV-STEL is defined as a 15-minute TWA exposure which should not be exceeded at any time during a workday even if the 8-hour TWA is within the TLV-TWA.  Exposures above the TLV-TWA up to the STEL should not be longer than 15 minutes and should not occur more than four times per day.

The National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH) IDLH value is 10 PPM.  The IDLH represents the maximum concentration from which, in the event of respirator failure, one could escape within 30 minutes without a respirator and without experiencing any escape-impairing (e.g. severe eye irritation) of irreversible health effects.

4.1.1.4  Corrosivity Data
Dry chlorine (liquid or gas) is non-corrosive to carbon steel.  In the presence of moisture, however, highly corrosive conditions exist as a result of the formation of hydrochloric and hypochlorous acids.  Dry chlorine will react with titanium to cause corrosion or combustion.  Stainless steels may fail due to chloride-stress corrosion cracking in the presence of moist chlorine. (Ref 4-1)

4.1.1.5  Stability Data
Chlorine is non-combustible in air but most combustible materials will burn in chlorine as they do in oxygen.  Flammable gases and vapors will form explosive mixtures with chlorine.  The volume of liquid chlorine increases considerably with increasing temperature.  Excessive temperatures will cause container failure or failure of container relief systems resulting in a chlorine release to atmosphere.

Ignition limits depe

nd on temperature, pressure, and concentration.  At 70-80°F, the ignition limits range from 3% to 93% by volume of hydrogen.

4.1.1.6  Mixing With Other Materials
 
Chlorine reacts explosively or forms explosive compounds with many common chemicals, especially acetylene, turpentine, ether, ammonia gas, fuel gas, hydrocarbons, hydrogen and metal shavings or dust from mechanical processes. Contact with combustible substances (such as gasoline and petroleum products and others) and finely divided metals may cause fires and explosions. (Refs 4-1 & 4-2)

4.1.4.1  Process Description
This section will provide a general description of the chlorination system and the function of the principle components.  A block flow diagram of the chlorination process is indicated in Figure 4-1 along with the chlorine feed system safety controls for the pumping station.  Chlorine gas (under pressure) from the one ton cylinder is routed to the vacuum regulators.  These vacuum regulators are mounted on the ton containers with a yoke and valve vacuum regulator arrangement attached to a valve on the upper portion of the cylinder.  The vacuum regulator serves to reduce the supply pressure from the ton container to a regulated vacuum for safe transport of the chlorine gas.  A liquid chlorine trap is installed on each vacuum regulator. It consists of a drip leg pipe that is heated with an AC powered heating tab arrangement that is attached to the drip leg. These liquid chlorine traps are used to catch and evaporate any liquid chlorine or condensed gas vapors which might enter the piping system.

From the vacuum regulators, chlorine gas is piped to the chlorine feed points on the water main or water supply line.  The chlorinators serve as flow regulators which control the amount of chlorine sent to the chlorine injectors, or ejectors.

 
The injectors are devices which create a vacuum by using a pressure difference created by the use of low pressure raw water coming from the wells and high pressure water coming from the booster pump flowing through a venturi.  This cre

ates a sufficient vacuum to draw the chlorine gas from the vacuum regulators through the chlorinators and to the ejectors.  A minimum of 12 inches of water vacuum is required.  In the injectors, chlorine gas is mixed with supply line water creating a solution of chlorinated water.  The chlorine solution is routed to various contact points were it is mixed with treated or partially treated water.

Chlorine solution is added to the water for several purposes.  The total chlorine solution used at the pump stations is for disinfection of water prior to discharge to water distribution system. 

4.1.4.2  Process Chemistry
When gaseous chlorine (Cl2) gas is added to water, two reactions take place: hydrolysis and ionization.(Reference 4-3)  The hydrolysis process is depicted in the following equation:

CL2 + H20   HOCL + H+ + CL-

HOCL will further ionize as follows:

HOCL   H+ + OCL-

The relative distribution of HOCL and OCL- in the water varies with HOCL having a much more significant disinfecting affect (40-80 times greater) than OCL-.  The distribution is a function of water temperature and pH.

4.1.4.6  Relief Features
The chlorine system employs several relief systems which are described as follows:

Ton Container Fusible Plugs - The one-ton chlorine containers in which the chlorine is delivered by the supplier, each have several (typically six) fusible plugs.  These plugs are intended to relieve pressure (and container contents) when the external temperature is in the range of 158-165oF (70-74oC). The fusible metal is designed to melt or yield to relieve

pressure and prevent rupture of the container in the case of fire or other exposure to high temperature.

Vacuum Regulator - Pressurized chlorine gas from the one ton chlorine cylinders is sent directly from the cylinder valve into the vacuum regulator.  A vacuum condition, created in the feed line by the ejector which is in line of the water supply opens the inlet valve to admit chlorine gas into the regulator.  A diaphragm regulates the vacuum at this point to a closely controlled value.  The system is completely under vacuum from the ejector to the gas inlet valve at the vacuum regulator during operation.  If the water supply to the ejector is stopped, or the operating vacuum is lost for any reason, the spring-loaded gas inlet valve immediately closes to isolate the chlorine supply.  Any gas, under pressure, which might enter the regulator, is vented from the system through the built-in pressure relief valve through a chlorine vent line to the atmosphere outside the Chlorine Storage Room.  If the source of chlorine gas is exhausted, a gas port on the vacuum regulator closes to prevent excess vacuum levels from developing upstream of the vacuum regulator and also prevents any moisture from being drawn back into the operating components or the gas supply lines.

Additionally, the vacuum regulator features a liquid trap which will trap any liquid chlorine which might enter the regulator.  A liquid chlorine trap consists of a drip leg pipe that is heated with an AC powered heating tab arrangement that is attached to a drop leg. This set up vaporizes the liquid chlorine into chlorine gas.  If liquid chlorine were drawn into the chlorine vacuum lines, and the lines were subsequently isolated by shutting valves, the trapped liquid could cause excessive pressure in the lines due to its 3:1 expansion rate from liquid to gas which could result in a feed line rupture.

Injector check valve - Each ejector is equipped with a check valve to protect the vacuum regulator f

rom flooding.

4.4 	TRAINING

The water system operator/maintainers must be properly trained in the operation of the chlorination process and informed of safety hazards.  The benefits of  a good training program is trained workers have fewer accidents, damage less equipment, and improve operational efficiency.  The training program, including refresher training, is the key to ensuring that he rest of the prevention program is effective.

For a Program 2 process there is no requirement to provide a specific amount of training or type of training.  The training program for the Kalamazoo water operator/maintainers has been developed to suite this operation.  In addition to training all new operator/maintainers, refresher training will be provided at least every three years, or more frequently if the chlorination process is changed.

Planning and developing the chlorination system training will consider the following items:
a.	Employee's who require the training will be clearly identified.
b.	A training outline will be developed to indicate what's included in the training.
c.	Specific training objectives will be developed.
d.	The training will consist of a combination of class room and on-the-job training.
e.	Employee competence will be measured using written tests and observations by the supervisor.
f.	All training will be documented in the Environmental Services Training Database.
